Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ion Irradiation-Induced Nanocrystallization of Metallic Glasses and Its Effects on Their Mechanical Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The main objectives of this collaborative research project are to develop an understanding of the mechanisms responsible for nanocrystal phase formation when metallic glasses are subjected to ion irradiation, and to quantify the resulting effects on the materials' mechanical behavior. The project will employ monomer-ion irradiation, ion irradiation at elevated temperatures, and cluster ion irradiation to promote direct crystallization of cascade regions so as to achieve tunable crystal densities, sizes and distributions. This portion of the work will contribute to fundamental understanding of radiation responses of metallic glasses including details of ion irradiation induced structural evolution occurring over different time scales involving damage cascade creation, thermal spike formation, and structural relaxation. The project will utilize nanoindentation and micro pillar compression experiments to quantify resulting hardness, elastic modulus and ductility. This portion of work will identify the roles of nanocrystals on the mechanical response of metallic glasses, and contribute to fundamental understanding of shear band nucleation and propagation, and deflection and attenuation by nanocrystals of different mechanical strengths and interaction cross sections.

It is expected that this study will contribute to new fundamental understanding of the mechanisms responsible for the creation of nanocrystals in metallic glasses by ion irradiation, and the role of the altered structures in the modification of the materials' mechanical response. Ion irradiation will be used as a method to precisely introduce excessive free volume into a metallic glass, and will therefore provide a means to understand its intrinsic properties, i.e., the role of free volume in determining amorphous-to-crystalline transitions. With nanocrystals embedded in an amorphous matrix acting as stress release centers, the ion beam modified surface is expected to demonstrate enhanced ductility for a wide range of materials applications in harsh environments. The study represents a strong collaboration which reaches across both institutional bounds (university and government laboratories) as well as interdisciplinary bounds (materials science, nuclear engineering, mechanical engineering and applied physics). In addition, the nature of this cross-disciplinary collaboration and the involvement of researchers from several disciplines support the broad dissemination of research results. The proposed effort also includes the integration of our research findings into existing courses at participant universities, and the development of an e-learning module on relevant topics. The project is planned to promote research involvement of underrepresented groups, both as graduate students and undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work was aimed at developing an understanding of the mechanisms responsible for nanocrystal phase formation when metallic glasses are subjected to ion irradiation, and in quantifying the resulting effects on the materials’ mechanical behavior. It was an extensive collaborative effort involving Oklahoma State University (OSU), Texas A & M University (TAMU), Tohoku University and the Center for Integrated Nanotechnologies (CINT) at Los Alamos and Sandia National Laboratories. The findings of this work have contributed to a fundamental understanding of the effects of ion irradiation on the hardness, elastic behavior and ductility of metallic glasses. Ion irradiation performed at room temperature, which introduces excess free volume in metallic glasses, was seen to result in a lower hardness and elastic modulus, and to shift the mechanism of deformation toward less shear localization and more homogeneous plastic flow. The observation of more homogeneous deformation implies an increased ductility and is consistent with the fact that metallic glasses with higher concentrations of free volume can accommodate local shear strain and deter the propagation of shear bands. Performing irradiation of the metallic glasses at elevated temperatures, which annihilates free volume, was seen to reduce the effects of room temperature irradiation on the elastic modulus and hardness as well as on the relative proportion of inhomogeneous to homogeneous deformation. These findings will benefit a wide range of metallic glass applications where increased ductility is required.  The work to date has resulted in five journal papers, a manuscript under review and several manuscripts in preparation. The project supported one female Ph.D. student and in terms of outreach, provided the opportunity for local high school students to participate in hands on laboratories to learn about various techniques used for the characterization of these metallic glasses.


Last Modified: 12/29/2016
Modified by: Don A Lucca

It was an extensive collaborative effort involving Oklahoma State University (OSU), Texas A & M University (TAMU), Tohoku University and the Center for Integrated Nanotechnologies (CINT) at Los Alamos and Sandia National Laboratories. The findings of this work have contributed to a fundamental understanding of the effects of ion irradiation on the hardness, elastic behavior and ductility of metallic glasses. Ion irradiation performed at room temperature, which introduces excess free volume in metallic glasses, was seen to result in a lower hardness and elastic modulus, and to shift the mechanism of deformation toward less shear localization and more homogeneous plastic flow. The observation of more homogeneous deformation implies an increased ductility and is consistent with the fact that metallic glasses with higher concentrations of free volume can accommodate local shear strain and deter the propagation of shear bands. Performing irradiation of the metallic glasses at elevated temperatures, which annihilates free volume, was seen to reduce the effects of room temperature irradiation on the elastic modulus and hardness as well as on the relative proportion of inhomogeneous to homogeneous deformation. These findings will benefit a wide range of metallic glass applications where increased ductility is required. The project supported one female Ph.D. student and in terms of outreach, provided the opportunity for local high school students to participate in hands on laboratories to learn about various techniques used for the characterization of these metallic glasses.
